DataElement.preferredName: Radionuclide Imaging Agent Assay Timepoint Dose Assay Net Radioactive Activity Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The net radioactive activity of the radionuclide imaging agent at the time of the dose assay represented as a numerical value.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Procedure Agents Domain Radionuclide Imaging Agent Dose Assay Timepoint Net Radioactive Activity
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to agents used as part of a procedure._An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ._An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect._A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time._A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug._A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event._Ultimate; final; remaining after all deductions, outlay, or loss._Parameter used to quantify radioactivity and represents radioactive source transformations, i.e. disintegrations or emissions, per unit time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to agents used as part of a procedure.

Concepts.definition: A domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to agents used as part of a procedure.

Property.preferredName: Radionuclide Imaging Agent Dose Assay Timepoint Net Radioactive Activity
Property.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ.:An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.:A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.:A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug.:A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.:Ultimate; final; remaining after all deductions, outlay, or loss.:Parameter used to quantify radioactivity and represents radioactive source transformations, i.e. disintegrations or emissions, per unit time.

Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ.
An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.
A quantity of an agent (such as substance or energy) administered, taken, or absorbed at one time.
A qualitative or quantitative analysis performed to determine the amount of a particular constituent in a sample or the biological or pharmacological properties of a drug.
A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event.
Ultimate; final; remaining after all deductions, outlay, or loss.
Parameter used to quantify radioactivity and represents radioactive source transformations, i.e. disintegrations or emissions, per unit time.
